header.title: The Lesser Key of Solomon: Goetia

central_thesis: The text presents King Solomon's system for invoking and commanding 72 infernal spirits through specific ceremonial rituals, magical apparatus, and divine names, while simultaneously proposing a 'materialistic rational' interpretation wherein these magical phenomena are understood as psychological operations that stimulate specific faculties within the human brain.

structure_content.summary: This section introduces the 'Lemegeton' (specifically, the First Book, Goetia) and its translation from ancient manuscripts by 'G. H. Fra. D.D.C.F.' (identified with Samuel Liddell MacGregor Mathers) and completion by Aleister Crowley. It then provides a foundational philosophical argument, asserting that magical phenomena are 'brain-changes' and 'spirits of the Goetia are portions of the human brain.' This 'materialistic rational statement' aims to reconcile magic with science by positing that rituals and divine names serve to stimulate and regulate specific mental faculties (e.g., 'The Spirit Cimieries teaches logic' implies developing logical faculty through the invocation process). It contrasts traditional views with this internal, psychological model, setting the tone for a deeper understanding of the grimoire's practical instructions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Overview of the Lemegeton and Goetia
structure_content.summary: The book details the five divisions of the Lemegeton, or Clavicula Salomonis Regis: (1) Goetia, concerning evil spirits and Solomon's method of binding them; (2) Theurgia-Goetia, dealing with mixed good and evil aerial spirits; (3) Ars Paulina, for spirits governing planetary hours and zodiacal degrees; (4) Ars Almadel of Solomon, for spirits ruling the Four Altitudes; and (5) Ars Nova or Notary Art, comprising orations and prayers revealed by the angel Michael. The focus of this particular text is primarily on the Goetia, 'The Book Of Evil Spirits,' outlining the names, orders, offices, seals, and methods for commanding its 72 infernal entities.

structure_content.chapter_title: Shemhamphorash: The 72 Spirits of the Goetia
structure_content.summary: This extensive section systematically enumerates and describes each of the 72 spirits, from Bael (1) to Andromalius (72). For each spirit, the text provides its numerical order, name(s), rank (King, Duke, Marquis, President, Earl, Knight), typical appearance or transformations, specific offices or abilities (e.g., making invisible, teaching languages, revealing past/future, causing love/hate, finding treasures, healing diseases), and the number of legions it commands. Crucially, each description concludes with the instruction that the spirit's 'Seal or Character' must be worn by the magician (often as a Lamen) for command and protection, and many entries include specific details for their evocation, such as direction, required offerings, or protective measures for the magician.

This section meticulously details the construction and use of essential magical tools. It describes the 'Magical Circle of Solomon' (a 9-foot diameter protective boundary), the 'Magical Triangle of Solomon' (a 2-foot distant, 3-foot wide triangular space for the spirit's appearance), the 'Hexagram of Solomon' (a figure on calf's skin for compelling human shape), the 'Pentagram of Solomon' (a gold or silver breastplate for protection), the 'Magic Ring or Disc of Solomon' (for protection from spirit's breath), and the 'Vessel of Brass' (for imprisoning spirits). It also specifies the 'Secret Seal of Solomon's' intricate creation process, including astrological timing, materials (virgin parchment, black cock's blood), and purpose. Additional requisites include a sceptre, sword, mitre, white robe, a lion's skin girdle inscribed with divine names, perfumes, chafing-dish, anointing oil, and fair water, accompanied by specific purification and vestment consecration rituals ('Adoration at the Bath' and 'Adoration at the Induing of the Vestments').

The operational core of the Goetia, this part provides the precise verbal formulas for summoning and controlling spirits. It includes the 'Preliminary Invocation' (to the Bornless One), 'The Conjuration to Call Forth Any of the Aforesaid Spirits' (First and Second), and 'The Constraint,' all employing extensive lists of divine and angelic names (e.g., ADONAI, TETRAGRAMMATON, EHYEH) to compel the spirit's appearance in a 'fair and comely shape.' Instructions are given for dealing with disobedience, including the 'Invocation of the King' (to command the four Great Kings - AMAIMON, CORSON, ZIMIMAY, GÖAP - to send subordinate spirits), 'The General Curse (Spirits' Chain),' 'The Conjuration of the Fire' (involving burning the spirit's seal in a metal box with brimstone), and 'The Greater Curse' (excommunication and binding to the 'Bottomless Abyss'). The section also details protocols for addressing, welcoming, and finally granting 'License to Depart' to the spirit, emphasizing the magician's authority and need for protective gear.

This concluding section provides a glossary of the numerous divine, angelic, and magical names used throughout the invocations and conjurations (e.g., Eheie, Iophiel, Tetragrammaton, Soluzen), offering their meanings and attributing their specific powers and functions within the magical system. It clarifies the significance of these names, many rooted in Qabalistic tradition, as instruments of authority and influence over the spirits. Additionally, it offers further explanations regarding the symbols and inscriptions found on the magical apparatus, ensuring the practitioner understands the energetic and symbolic resonance of each component within the ritual framework.

key_concepts.definition: The first book of the Lemegeton, containing instructions for invoking and commanding 72 infernal spirits, detailing their seals, offices, and forms.
A magical breastplate, typically made of metal or parchment and inscribed with a spirit's seal or character, worn by the magician for protection and authority during operations.
A primary protective boundary, typically 9 feet in diameter, inscribed with divine names and symbols, within which the exorcist stands during invocations to shield themselves from evil spirits.
A triangular space, positioned outside and 2-3 feet from the Magical Circle, into which the evoked spirit is commanded to appear and manifest visibly.
A six-pointed star figure, typically made on calf's skin and worn by the magician, used to compel spirits to take on a human shape and ensure their obedience.
A five-pointed star figure, made of gold or silver and worn on the magician's breast (with the spirit's seal on the reverse), serving for protection and to command the spirits.
A magical container, similar to the one Solomon used to imprison evil spirits, implied to be used to contain or bind summoned entities.

A potent seal crafted under precise astrological conditions (Mars or Saturn night, increasing moon in Virgo, virgin parchment, black cock's blood), used to bind spirits and grant the magician various powers, including love, victory in battle, and invulnerability.

Specific Hebrew and other holy names of God and angels (e.g., ADONAI, TETRAGRAMMATON, EHYEH) used as words of power in invocations, conjurations, and curses to assert the magician's authority over the spirits.

A core philosophical tenet of this edition, positing that magical phenomena, including the appearance and actions of spirits, are internal psychological events or 'brain-changes,' and that the spirits themselves represent 'portions of the human brain' or specific mental faculties.
A hierarchy of infernal entities, each with distinct characteristics, forms, abilities, and legions, detailed in the Goetia and subject to the magician's command through specific rituals and seals.

practical_system.description: The Goetic system outlined is a method for ritually invoking and commanding 72 infernal spirits to perform various tasks, answer questions, or impart knowledge. The practitioner, through a series of elaborate conjurations and protective measures, aims to compel these entities into visible manifestation within a designated magical triangle. Philosophically, the entire operation is presented as an intricate psychological process designed to awaken and control specific brain functions or internal archetypes, with the spirits serving as externalized representations of these internal states. The system emphasizes rigorous preparation, adherence to precise ritual protocols, and the use of consecrated magical tools.

relevant_quotes.text: The spirits of the Goetia are portions of the human brain.
Their seals therefore represent (...) methods of stimulating or regulating those particular spots (through the eye).

If, then, I say, with Solomon: 'The Spirit Cimieries teaches logic,' what I mean is: 'Those portions of my brain which subserve the logical faculty may be stimulated and developed by following out the processes called 'The Invocation of Cimieries.''

This translation of the FIRST BOOK of the 'Lemegeton' (...) was done (...) by G. H. Fra. D.D.C.F., by the order of the Secret Chief of the Rosicrucian Order. (...) it seemed expedient that the work should be brought to its conclusion by another hand. The investigation of a competent Skryer (...) confirmed this divination (...) but only the terrible shapes of the evil Adepts S.V.A. and H., whose original bodies having been sequestered by Justice, were no longer of use to them. (...) did decide to ask Mr. Aleister Crowley, a poet, and skilled student of Magical Lore, and an expert Kabbalist, to complete openly that which had been begun in secret.
This is the Form of the Magical Circle of King Solomon, the which he made that he might preserve himself therein from the malice of these Evil Spirits.

This seal is to be made by one that is clean both inwardly and outwardly, and that hath not defiled himself by any woman in the space of a month, but hath in prayer and fasting desired of God to forgive him all his sins, etc.

I DO invocate and conjure thee, O Spirit, N.'; and being with power armed from the SUPREME MAJESTY, I do strongly command thee, by BERALANENSIS, BALDACHIENSIS, PAUMACHIA, and APOLOGIAE SEDES; by the most Powerful Princes, Genii, Liachidsæ, and Ministers of the Tartarean Abode; and by the Chief Prince of the Seat of Apologia in the Ninth Legion, I do invoke thee, and by invocating conjure thee.

critical_analysis.relevance: This edition of the Goetia holds significant relevance in Western Esotericism due to its historical context and the philosophical interpretation introduced by Aleister Crowley. It bridges traditional grimoire material with a modern occult perspective, providing a psychological framework for understanding magical operations, which was groundbreaking at the time. This approach allows practitioners to engage with 'demonology' not just as literal spirit contact, but as a method for self-exploration and the development of internal faculties. Its detailed descriptions of spirits and their seals have made it a foundational text for various magical traditions, including Thelema and subsequent forms of ceremonial magic, influencing generations of occultists.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this book includes experienced practitioners of ceremonial magic, students of Qabalah, Hermeticism, and grimoire traditions, as well as academic researchers interested in the intersection of psychology and occultism. It assumes a foundational understanding of esoteric concepts and a serious commitment to magical practice, making it less suitable for casual readers or beginners without prior exposure to occult literature.
